questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines is generally not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Hepatitis B
  2. Influenza
  3. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  4. Pneumococcal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c only

 

HPV vaccine is not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age because it is only approved for use up to 45 years of age. The other vaccines mentioned can be safely and effectively administered to elderly individuals based on their risk factors and previous vaccination status.

 

Other Options:

 

a. Hepatitis B vaccine: This is conditionally indicated in elderly individuals who have not previously received the vaccine and have risk factors.

 

b. Influenza vaccine: This is strongly recommended annually for elderly individuals as they are at high risk for complications from influenza infection.

 

d. Pneumococcal vaccine: This is a crucial vaccine for elderly individuals. The current recommendation in India is to give PCV13 followed by PPSV23 to provide comprehensive protection against pneumococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The age-based restrictions for HPV vaccination (approved only up to age 45) and the core vaccines recommended for elderly individuals (pneumococcal, influenza, and conditional hepatitis B vaccination).

 

The only non-recommended vaccine in this list for those over 65 years is HPV, while pneumococcal, influenza, and hepatitis B vaccines may all be indicated based on individual risk factors and previous vaccination status.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: Which of the following is lined by simple squamous epithelium? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Loop of Henle

 

Explanation: 

                                   

Loop of Henle is lined by simple squamous epithelium. This specialized thin epithelium facilitates passive diffusion and reabsorption of water and electrolytes. The flattened cells with their minimal thickness are perfectly suited for the Loop of Henle's function in the renal tubular system, allowing efficient transport across the epithelial layer.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) - PCT is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with a prominent brush border. These cuboidal cells have numerous microvilli that increase surface area for active reabsorption of filtered substances.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. These cells have fewer microvilli than PCT cells but contain numerous mitochondria to support active transport processes.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - Collecting ducts are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. In some regions, particularly deeper parts, the epithelium may become columnar, but it is never squamous.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Simple squamous epithelium is found in areas requiring rapid transport, diffusion, or filtration such as the Loop of Henle, alveoli of lungs, and endothelium of blood vessels due to its thin, flattened morphology that facilitates these functions.

questions.text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea, delayed wound healing. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

 

The case describes a classic presentation of zinc deficiency with the characteristic Features:

 

  1. Periorificial dermatitis (perioral and perianal rash as shown in images)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Delayed wound healing

 

The mnemonic "HIDE" helps remember the key features of zinc deficiency:

 

  • H: Healing (delayed wound healing)
  • I: Immunity (decreased)
  • D: Dermatitis (periorificial/acral)
  • E: Enteropathy (diarrhea)

 

Additional features can include:

 

  • Alopecia (hair loss)
  • Growth retardation
  • Impaired taste sensation
  • Secondary infections due to compromised immunity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents with pellagra characterized by 3Ds: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia
  • Dermatitis in pellagra shows casal’s Necklace appearance on sun-exposed areas, not periorificial
  • Dementia is not present in this case

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents as Keshan disease with cardiomyopathy
  • Does not cause characteristic periorificial lesions or diarrhea
  • More common in areas with selenium-deficient soil

 

Option D. Magnesium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Primarily presents with neuromuscular symptoms like tetany and seizures
  • Does not cause characteristic skin lesions or chronic diarrhea
  • Usually associated with malabsorption or alcoholism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the characteristic clinical presentation of zinc deficiency using the mnemonic "HIDE" - Healing (delayed), Immunity (decreased), Dermatitis (periorificial), and Enteropathy (diarrhea). The periorificial distribution of dermatitis is pathognomonic for zinc deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities are likely to be associated with imperforate anus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Esophageal atresia

 

Explanation:

 

Anorectal malformations (including imperforate anus) commonly occur with other congenital anomalies. The sacrum and genitourinary tract are often abnormal in these patients. Esophageal atresia frequently coexists with imperforate anus as part of the VACTERL association, where the "A" stands for anorectal malformations and the "E" for esophageal atresia. This embryological connection makes esophageal atresia the most likely associated abnormality from the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Pulmonary airway malformation): Not typically associated with anorectal malformations. While respiratory abnormalities can occur in complex syndromes, this specific malformation is not a common association.
  • Option B (Duodenal atresia): Though duodenal atresia is a significant congenital malformation, it has stronger associations with Down syndrome rather than with imperforate anus.
  • Option D (Hydrocephalus): Not commonly associated with imperforate anus. Neurological conditions are not typical components of the syndromes that include anorectal malformations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Imperforate anus frequently occurs with other congenital anomalies, particularly those affecting the sacrum, genitourinary tract, and other components of the VACTERL association, which includes esophageal atresia.

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is known as a synchondrosis. Synchondrosis is a type of primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. In the context of long bones, this joint occurs between the epiphyseal plate (growth plate) and the diaphysis during the development of the bone.

 

The epiphyseal plate is a layer of hyaline cartilage that allows the bone to grow in length. As growth continues, this cartilage eventually undergoes ossification, transforming into bone and thereby eliminating the synchondrosis joint, marking the end of growth in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue. It does not involve cartilage and is therefore not applicable to the junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis.

 

Option C. Synarthrosis: Synarthrosis refers to an immovable joint. While synchondrosis could be considered a type of synarthrosis when ossified, it specifically refers to the cartilaginous joint prior to ossification. Thus, this option is less specific and not the correct answer in this context.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by fibrocartilage. It is typically found in the midline of the body, such as the pubic symphysis or the intervertebral discs. This type of joint does not describe the connection between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

questions.text: The space between bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hiatus Semilunaris

 

Explanation: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is the gap between the bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process. It represents a two-dimensional space with a width of approximately 1-2mm. The uncinate process is a hook-like structure that runs from anterosuperior to posteroinferior direction, with its sharp posterosuperior border running parallel to the anterior border of the bulla ethmoidalis, creating this distinctive gap.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agger nasi :This is an elevation located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatized, it contains agger nasi cells which may communicate with the frontal recess, but it is not the space between the bulla and uncinate process.

 

Option B. Olfactory cleft: This refers to the superior part of the nasal cavity where the olfactory epithelium is located, between the upper part of the septum and superior turbinate. It has no relation to the bulla ethmoidalis or uncinate process.

 

Option C. Frontonasal duct: This is an incorrect term that was historically used to describe the drainage pathway from the frontal sinus. No true duct exists; rather, the frontal sinus drains through the frontal recess into the middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The hiatus semilunaris is a critical landmark in the ostiomeatal complex, serving as an important reference point during endoscopic sinus surgery and forming part of the pathway for drainage of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue and pallor. Investigations show Hb = 5.8 gm/dl, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, high RDW. Diagnosis is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron Deficiency Anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin levels, low ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), high total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and high red cell distribution width (RDW). These laboratory findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Low ferritin indicates depleted iron stores.
  • High TIBC reflects an increase in the body's attempt to capture more iron due to deficiency.
  • Low MCV signifies microcytic anemia, common in iron deficiency.
  • High RDW indicates variability in red cell size, often seen in iron deficiency as the body produces new, smaller red cells alongside older, larger ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Megaloblastic Anemia: Typically presents with high MCV (macrocytic anemia) due to deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate, not low MCV.

 

Option C. Anemia of Chronic Disease: Often presents with normal or high ferritin (reflecting inflammation or infection) and low TIBC, not high TIBC.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic Anemia: Generally associated with increased iron stores, not low ferritin, and may show a dimorphic blood picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is indicated by low hemoglobin, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, and high RDW.

questions.text: A person with history of RTA admitted in hospital. He is able to understand what his friend is talking but he is unable to speak. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured in this case? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Broca's area

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient is able to understand spoken language but is unable to speak, indicating that comprehension is intact while fluency is impaired. This condition is characteristic of Broca's aphasia, which results from damage to Broca's area in the frontal lobe of the brain.

 

Broca's area is responsible for speech production and language processing. Damage to this area leads to non-fluent aphasia, where the patient struggles to form words and sentences despite understanding spoken language. This condition is often seen in individuals who have experienced a stroke or traumatic brain injury.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension. The patient would not understand spoken language.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus: Damage to the angular gyrus typically results in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: acalculia (difficulty with calculations), agraphia (difficulty writing), right-left confusion, and finger agnosia.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus causes conduction aphasia, where the patient has intact comprehension and fluency but cannot repeat words or phrases.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Broca's area damage results in Broca's aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production with intact comprehension.

choices.text: Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation

questions.text: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for the shorter bedaquiline regimen in the treatment of tuberculosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive TB

 

The shorter bedaquiline regimen is specifically designed for treating certain cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis. It is typically indicated in cases of Rifampicin-resistant (RR) tuberculosis or multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis under certain conditions. This regimen is used when the tuberculosis strain is resistant to Rifampicin, but it remains sensitive to fluoroquinolones.

 

Additionally, in cases where there is resistance to Isoniazid (INH), the shorter regimen can be used if the resistance is due to a mutation in either the KatG or inhA gene, but not both.

 

If both mutations are present, or if the TB is severe or extrapulmonary, the shorter regimen is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extrapulmonary TB like Tubercular meningitis: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for extrapulmonary TB, as it is intended for pulmonary TB only. Extrapulmonary TB often requires a longer and more complex treatment regimen.

 

Option B. Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation: This scenario represents a more complex form of MDR-TB where resistance occurs due to mutations in both the KatG and inhA genes. The presence of both mutations generally excludes the use of the shorter regimen, as a longer and more intensive treatment is required.

 

Option C. Rifampicin-sensitive TB: The shorter bedaquiline regimen is not indicated for Rifampicin-sensitive TB. This regimen is specifically designed for drug-resistant cases, particularly those resistant to Rifampicin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline shorter regimen is indicated for the treatment of -

 

  • Rifampicin-resistant TB (FQ sensitive) or MDR TB
  • INH Resistant TB – due to mutation in either inhA or Kat G gene (NOT BOTH)
  • Pulmonary TB

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text: A young woman wants to take the post-coital pill. Which one should be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LNG

 

The post-coital pill, also known as emergency contraception, is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. The preferred choice for emergency contraception, particularly in many countries including India, is Levonorgestrel (LNG).

 

LNG (Levonorgestrel): Available under brand names such as the "easy pill," it contains 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to effectively prevent pregnancy. It is a single-dose regimen that is well-tolerated and has fewer side effects compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Norethisterone: This is not used for emergency contraception. It is primarily used in other hormonal treatments, such as for menstrual disorders.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen alone is not used for emergency contraception due to the risk of side effects and its lower efficacy compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option D. Estrogen + Progesterone (Yuzpe regimen): Although this method can be used for emergency contraception, it is not preferred due to the higher incidence of side effects like nausea and vomiting. This method involves taking a high dose of estrogen and progesterone and repeating it after 12 hours, which is less convenient and less well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred emergency contraceptive pill is Levonorgestrel (LNG), to be taken as a single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: Which nerve injury is associated with winging of the scapula? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Long thoracic nerve of Bell

 

Explanation:

 

Winging of the scapula occurs due to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which is supplied by the long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7). When damaged, the medial border of the scapula protrudes from the posterior chest wall, especially when the patient pushes against resistance. The person is unable to perform pushing or punching movements, and overhead abduction of the arm is affected. The serratus anterior normally holds the scapula against the thoracic wall, and its paralysis leads to this characteristic deformity where the inferior angle of the scapula becomes prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve: Supplies intrinsic hand muscles and causes ulnar claw hand when injured. It has no relation to the scapular muscles or position.

 

Option C. Lower subscapular nerve: Supplies the teres major and part of the subscapularis muscles. Its injury would affect shoulder rotation but not cause scapular winging.

 

Option D. Thoracodorsal nerve: Supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. Injury to this nerve affects extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the arm but does not cause winging of the scapula.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Winging of the scapula is pathognomonic of serratus anterior paralysis due to long thoracic nerve (Bell's nerve) injury, making it impossible for the patient to press against a wall without the medial border of scapula becoming abnormally prominent.

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

choices.text: Relative constriction of the shaft of the penis

questions.text: An accused in a sodomy case is brought for a medical examination. Upon questioning, he reveals that he is the active agent and a regular participant. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be present during his examination? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Presence of smegma

 

Explanation:

 

In a habitual active agent of sodomy, smegma would be unlikely to be present. Smegma is a thick, cheesy secretion that accumulates under the prepuce and around the corona glandis. This substance gets rubbed off during sexual intercourse and takes approximately 24 hours to redeposit. Since the question mentions the accused is a "regular participant" as an active agent, the repeated sexual activity would prevent smegma accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fecal smell - This is an expected finding in an active agent of sodomy. The forensic examination typically reveals traces of feces and lubricant about the genitalia along with the peculiar smell of anal glands, making this a common finding during examination.

 

Option C. Tear of frenulum - This can be present in an active agent, especially when forceful penetration occurs against resistance. Forceful penetration may produce tears or bruising of the frenulum or prepuce and abrasion of the glans penis.

 

Option D. Relative constriction of the shaft of the penis - This is a characteristic finding in habitual active agents of sodomy. The penis usually becomes twisted with constriction at some distance from the glans due to the constricting force of the sphincter ani during repeated anal intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sodomy examination, the absence of smegma is significant forensic evidence of recent sexual activity in the active partner, while other physical findings like distinctive odors, penile constriction patterns, and trauma to frenulum are typically present in habitual active agents.

questions.text: All of the following are unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Median sacral artery

 

 

The median sacral artery is not an anterior branch of the abdominal aorta, but rather a terminal branch that arises from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation into the common iliac arteries. It descends in the midline anterior to the sacrum and coccyx. This artery is unpaired but is not classified as an anterior branch due to its position and point of origin.

 

The main unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta include the celiac trunk (T12-L1), superior mesenteric artery (L1), and inferior mesenteric artery (L3), which supply the foregut, midgut, and hindgut respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac trunk - This is indeed an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of T12-L1. It divides into the left gastric, splenic, and common hepatic arteries and supplies the foregut derivatives.

 

Option B. Inferior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L3. It supplies the hindgut derivatives including the left one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and upper rectum.

 

Option C. Superior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L1. It supplies the midgut derivatives including the small intestine, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, and right two-thirds of the transverse colon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The abdominal aorta has three major unpaired anterior branches (celiac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery) that supply the three embryological divisions of the gut, while the median sacral artery is a terminal branch arising from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation.

questions.text: A study was done in 3 districts to measure the mean blood pressure. Health workers visited each house of the 3 districts. Identify the epidemiological study design. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross sectional study.

 

A cross-sectional study involves collecting data at a single point in time from a population or a representative subset to assess the prevalence of outcomes or characteristics, such as mean blood pressure. In this case, health workers visited each house in the three districts at the same time to measure blood pressure, making it a cross-sectional study. This type of study is also known as a "snapshot study" or "prevalence study" because it provides a picture of the population's health status at one point in time, allowing the calculation of prevalence rates for conditions like hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case control study: This design involves comparing individuals with a particular condition (cases) to those without it (controls) and looking retrospectively to identify exposures. Since the study described is not retrospective and does not involve comparing cases to controls, it is not a case control study.

 

Option C. Cohort study: A cohort study follows a group of individuals over time to see how certain exposures affect outcomes. The study in question does not follow participants over time but rather assesses them at one point in time, ruling out the cohort study design.

 

Option D. Ecological study: An ecological study looks at data at the group or population level rather than individual level, often using existing data. The study described involves direct data collection from individuals, making it unsuitable as an ecological study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cross-sectional study collects data from a population at one point in time, often used to determine the prevalence of a condition like hypertension.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in newborn, born with which condition?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

 

The INSURE technique stands for INtubate, SURfactant, and Extubate. This method is used primarily in the management of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease. The procedure involves:

 

  1. Intubating the newborn to establish a secure airway.
  2. Administering surfactant directly into the lungs to reduce surface tension and improve lung function.
  3. Extubating the newborn after the surfactant has been given to allow for spontaneous breathing with the aid of non-invasive ventilation, if necessary.

 

Hyaline membrane disease occurs in preterm infants due to the immaturity of the lungs and a deficiency of surfactant, a substance that prevents the alveoli in the lungs from collapsing. The INSURE technique is effective in providing the necessary surfactant and reducing the severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This option is incorrect because meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in post-term infants who inhale meconium-stained amniotic fluid, leading to respiratory distress. The INSURE technique is not used for this condition.

 

Option B. Transiente tachypnea of newborn: This option is incorrect because transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limited condition seen in term infants caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. It typically resolves without the need for surfactant administration.

 

Option D. Neonatal jaundice: This option is incorrect because neonatal jaundice, caused by elevated bilirubin levels, is not related to lung function or surfactant deficiency. The INSURE technique is not applicable to this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The INSURE technique (Intubate, Surfactant, Extubate) is primarily used in preterm infants with hyaline membrane disease to administer surfactant and improve lung function.

choices.text: Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children

questions.text: Which statement about Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) in children is accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children 

 

Explanation:

 

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children, after Minimal Change Disease (MCD). FSGS accounts for approximately 10-15% of pediatric nephrotic syndrome cases. It is characterized by sclerosis in parts (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli, with fusion of the foot processes of podocytes visible on electron microscopy.

 

FSGS is often associated with the NPHS2 gene mutation, which affects the protein podocin in the glomerular filtration barrier. This mutation is frequently linked to steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, making FSGS a significant cause of both primary and secondary steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in the pediatric population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Good response to steroids - INCORRECT. FSGS is typically characterized by poor response to steroids. Most cases are steroid-resistant, which is one of the indicators for performing a renal biopsy in children with nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Relapses are rare - INCORRECT. In FSGS, relapses are common, and the disease often follows a progressive course leading to end-stage renal disease in many patients if not effectively treated.

 

Option D. Renal biopsy is not required - INCORRECT. Renal biopsy is essential for diagnosing FSGS. It is indicated in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome and is the only definitive way to diagnose FSGS and distinguish it from other causes of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

FSGS is the second most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (after Minimal Change Disease), is typically steroid-resistant, requires renal biopsy for diagnosis, and has a higher risk of progression to end-stage renal disease compared to MCD.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal (medial) end of the clavicle is the ossification center used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage. This is a critical ossification center for age estimation in the late teens and early twenties. The secondary center at the medial end of the clavicle appears at around 18 years of age and fuses with the shaft by 21-22 years of age in males (slightly earlier in females).

 

In the context of legal consent to marriage, which typically requires individuals to be at least 18 years for females and 21 years for males in many jurisdictions, the fusion status of the medial end of the clavicle provides valuable evidence for age determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end (Incorrect) The acromial (lateral) end of the clavicle is not commonly used for age determination related to legal consent for marriage as it fuses earlier and doesn't provide relevant age information for the late teens to early twenties.

 

Option C. Shaft (Incorrect) The shaft (body) of the clavicle is the primary ossification center that appears very early (around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life) and is the first bone to begin ossification. It doesn't provide useful information for age estimation in the context of marriage consent.

 

Option D. Tubercle (Incorrect) The tubercle of the clavicle doesn't have a separate ossification center that would be relevant for age determination in the context of legal consent for marriage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial (sternal) end of the clavicle is a key marker for age estimation between 18-22 years, making it highly valuable for legal age determination in marriage consent cases.

choices.text: It is observed with sudden death
The stage of primary relaxation is absent
It can be simulated by cold stiffening
It indicates the time since death

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cadaveric spasm is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It indicates the time since death.

 

Explanation:

 

Cadaveric spasm does not indicate the time since death. It is an instantaneous postmortem phenomenon and is not useful for estimating postmortem interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is observed with sudden death - This statement is CORRECT. Cadaveric spasm occurs especially in cases of sudden death, excitement, fear, severe pain, exhaustion, cerebral hemorrhage, electrocution, injury to the nervous system, firearm wound of the head or convulsant poisons, like strychnine.

 

Option B. The stage of primary relaxation is absent - This statement is CORRECT. Cadaveric spasm is defined as a condition in which the muscles of the body which were in a state of contraction immediately before death continue to be so after death without passing through the stage of primary relaxation.

 

Option C. It indicates the time since death. Correct. Cold stiffening due to freezing can mimic cadaveric spasm

 

Key Distinguishing Features

 

Cadaveric spasm differs from other forms of postmortem stiffening:

  • It is instantaneous (no primary flaccidity)
  • Usually limited to a single group of muscles (often hands)
  • Occurs only in specific circumstances like sudden death

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cadaveric spasm is an immediate stiffening of muscles at the moment of sudden death, often indicating the deceased's last action (e.g., gripping a weapon), but it does not help estimate time of death.

 

Rigor mortis sets in gradually after death and is useful for estimating the postmortem interval and assessing if the body has been moved.

questions.text: Which virus is the most common cause of croup in children? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Parainfluenza 

 

Explanation: 

 

Parainfluenza virus (especially types 1 and 2) is the most common cause of croup in children, accounting for approximately 75% of all cases. Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is characterized by barky cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor resulting from inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic area. Parainfluenza virus causes inflammation and edema of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi, with the narrowest portion of the pediatric airway (subglottic region) being particularly affected.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) - Incorrect. RSV is the leading cause of bronchiolitis in children under 2 years of age, but it is not the primary causative agent of croup. RSV affects the lower respiratory tract, causing inflammation of the small airways (bronchioles).

 

Option B. Influenza - Incorrect. While influenza can cause croup-like symptoms, it is not the most common viral cause. Influenza typically causes more systemic symptoms like high fever, myalgia, and fatigue in addition to respiratory symptoms.

 

Option D. Streptococcus Pneumoniae - Incorrect. This is a bacterium, not a virus. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a major cause of bacterial pneumonia, otitis media, and sinusitis, but not typically associated with croup, which is predominantly viral in etiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza virus is the most common cause of viral croup in children, typically presenting with the classic triad of barky cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness, with symptoms often worsening at night.

questions.text: AMBU AURA40 is what generation LMA? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA because:

 

  • It has only one tube (the airway tube)
  • No separate gastric drainage channel
  • It is essentially a modified version of the classic LMA
  • The number "40" in its name indicates it can be used up to 40 times
  • It is unlike second-generation LMAs like Ambu AuraGain which have two tubes (airway and gastric drainage)

 



Educational Objective:

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA characterized by having only one tube for airway management without a separate gastric drainage channel.

 

Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) Generations

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: What is the length of the external auditory canal in an adult? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 mm

 

Explanation:

 

The external auditory canal in an adult measures about 24 mm along its posterior wall. This is the standard anatomical length of the external auditory canal. The canal is not straight but has a slight S-shape, with the outer part directed upwards, backwards, and medially, while the inner part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 16 mm: This is incorrect for the total length of the external auditory canal. However, 16 mm specifically represents the length of the bony part of the external auditory canal, which forms the inner two-thirds of the total canal.

 

Option B. 20 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is longer than 20 mm in adults.

 

Option D. 28 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is shorter than 28 mm in adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The external auditory canal in adults measures approximately 24 mm along its posterior wall and consists of a cartilaginous part (outer one-third, approximately 8 mm) and a bony part (inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm).

questions.text: Which hormone influences potassium ion concentration in the body? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Insulin

 

Explanation:   


Insulin is a key hormone that influences potassium ion concentration in the body. One of insulin's well-documented physiological effects is causing hypokalemia through its action on cell membranes. When insulin is secreted from pancreatic β cells, it produces a biphasic response - the immediate phase leads to glucose uptake into tissues and simultaneously causes hypokalemia as potassium moves into cells. This potassium-lowering effect is an important aspect of insulin's role in maintaining electrolyte homeostasis alongside its metabolic functions.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. GH (Growth Hormone) - Growth hormone primarily regulates growth and development of organs throughout the body. While it has multiple metabolic effects, it doesn't directly influence potassium ion concentration in any significant way.
  • Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) - FSH is a pituitary hormone involved in reproductive function. It works through the cAMP signaling pathway but has no documented role in potassium regulation or transport.
  • Option D. Oxytocin - Oxytocin functions through the IP3-DAG pathway and is primarily involved in uterine contraction and milk ejection. It doesn't participate in potassium homeostasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin plays a critical role in electrolyte balance by promoting cellular uptake of potassium, leading to decreased serum potassium levels (hypokalemia) along with its better-known effects on glucose metabolism.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent headaches, visual disturbances, and features of increased intracranial tension. CT imaging reveals a well-circumscribed brain lesion, and its biopsy shows psammoma bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meningioma

 

Meningioma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and histopathological findings. Meningiomas are typically well-circumscribed, slow-growing tumors arising from the arachnoid meningothelial cells. The hallmark histological finding of psammoma bodies—concentric rings of calcification—is characteristic of meningiomas. These tumors commonly present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure such as headaches and visual disturbances.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schwannoma: Incorrect. Schwannomas arise from Schwann cells of peripheral nerves or cranial nerves (most commonly CN VIII). They typically present with symptoms related to the affected nerve rather than generalized increased intracranial pressure. Histologically, they show Antoni A (hypercellular) and Antoni B (hypocellular) areas with Verocay bodies, not psammoma bodies.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Incorrect. Medulloblastomas are aggressive, highly malignant tumors that primarily affect children and typically arise in the cerebellum. They present with cerebellar symptoms and features of increased intracranial pressure due to obstruction of CSF flow. Histologically, they show small round blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Option C. Ependymoma: Incorrect. Ependymomas arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. They typically occur in children and young adults, often presenting with hydrocephalus due to CSF obstruction. Microscopically, they show perivascular pseudorosettes and true ependymal rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningiomas are characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) on histopathological examination and typically present as well-circumscribed lesions causing symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

choices.text: Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers
It can be used for resistant malaria
It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid
It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pretomanid? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

 

Explanation: 


Pretomanid is approved as part of the BPaL (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) regime for treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) and pre-XDR TB in India. This combination therapy represents a significant advancement in treating highly resistant forms of tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers: Incorrect. Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, not CYP2C9, and is contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

 

Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria: Incorrect. Pretomanid is specifically approved for tuberculosis treatment, not malaria.

 

Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species: Incorrect. Pretomanid acts by releasing reactive nitrogen species (not oxygen), which inhibit mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 


Pretomanid is part of the BPaL regimen (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) approved for treating XDR-TB and pre-XDR TB, and works through the release of reactive nitrogen species to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.

 

New Drugs:

 

  1. Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation
  2. Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation
  3. Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria

questions.text: Identify the structure being palpated in the image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

 

The image shows a hand palpating the area just behind the medial malleolus (the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle). The structure located in this region is the posterior tibial artery. This artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to the lower leg and foot. It can be palpated in this location to assess blood flow to the foot, and its pulse is an important clinical sign in assessing peripheral circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plantar artery: The plantar arteries are found on the sole of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the front of the lower leg, not behind the medial malleolus. It is not the structure being palpated in this image.

 

Option D. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the top of the foot, near the ankle, but it is not found behind the medial malleolus. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery can be palpated just behind the medial malleolus, and this is a key location for assessing the arterial blood supply to the foot.

questions.text: Referred pain from ureteric colic is felt in the groin due to involvement of the following nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. D) Genitofemoral

 

Explanation: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) is responsible for referred pain from ureteric colic felt in the groin. This nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch innervates the cremaster muscle and skin of the scrotum or labia majora, while the femoral branch supplies skin over the femoral triangle. When there is ureteric colic, the pain is referred along this nerve pathway to the groin area. The genitofemoral nerve is involved in the cremaster reflex, where scratching the inner thigh causes testicular elevation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Subcostal - This is a terminal branch of the T12 nerve that supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It doesn't have connections to the ureter that would explain referred pain to the groin.
  • Option B. Iliohypogastric - While this nerve (L1) is situated at the posterior surface of kidney, it primarily supplies the skin of the lower abdomen and hip region. It's not the main pathway for ureteric pain referred to the groin.
  • Option C. Ilioinguinal - This nerve (L1) supplies the inguinal region, upper part of scrotum, and root of penis or mons pubis in females. Though it runs near urological structures, it's not the primary nerve mediating referred ureteric pain to the groin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) serves as the primary pathway for referred pain from ureteric colic to the groin due to its anatomical course and innervation of genital structures.

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is commonly treated with stimulant medications, which are the first line of treatment. The main drugs of choice include methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine. These medications work by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving concentration and reducing impulsivity and hyperactivity.

 

Atomoxetine, although not a stimulant, is also used as a treatment option for ADHD. It works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is considered a non-stimulant alternative, especially useful in patients who may not respond well to stimulants or who have contraindications.

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine and duloxetine, are primarily used as antidepressants and are not typically used as first-line or preferred treatments for ADHD. These medications target different neurotransmitter systems and do not specifically address the core symptoms of ADHD as effectively as stimulants or atomoxetine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: alpha agonist: This is incorrect because methylphenidate is a stimulant and a common first-line treatment for ADHD, although it is not an alpha agonist. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain.

 

Option B. Dexmethylphenidate or Dextroamphetamine: Dexmethylphenidate is a derivative of methylphenidate and is also a drug of choice for ADHD, working similarly to increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels.

 

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant that is often used in the management of ADHD due to its efficacy in increasing dopamine and norepinephrine release, which helps in reducing ADHD symptoms.

 

Option C. Atomoxetine: antidepressant: Although it is referred to as an antidepressant, atomoxetine is actually a non-stimulant specifically approved for the treatment of ADHD, making it a valid option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.

 

Remember -

 

  • Drugs used:
  • Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • Dx methylphenidate
  • Dextro amphetamine
  • Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • Imipramine
  • Clonidine, guanfacine

questions.text: Among the following, which is the least common opportunistic fungus known to cause pulmonary infections in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sporothrix

 

Explanation:

 

Sporothrix is the least common opportunistic fungus among the given options to cause pulmonary infections in children. Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes sporotrichosis, which is typically a cutaneous infection that follows traumatic inoculation of the fungus into the skin, often through rose thorns or splinters (hence its nickname "rose gardener's disease"). Pulmonary sporotrichosis is extremely rare, especially in children, and is not typically considered among the common opportunistic pulmonary fungal infections.

 

 

The other listed fungi are more commonly associated with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect. Aspergillus is a common cause of opportunistic pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with prolonged neutropenia, chronic granulomatous disease, or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy. It can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and aspergilloma.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect. Cryptococcus (particularly C. neoformans) is a significant cause of pulmonary and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with HIV/AIDS or on immunosuppressive therapy. Pulmonary cryptococcosis is more common than pulmonary sporotrichosis.

 

Option D. Mucor - Incorrect. Mucor species (causing mucormycosis) are increasingly recognized as important opportunistic fungi in immunocompromised children, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, prolonged neutropenia, or those receiving deferoxamine therapy. Rhinocerebral and pulmonary mucormycosis are the most common clinical presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes cutaneous sporotrichosis following traumatic inoculation and is rarely associated with pulmonary infections in children, unlike Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, and Mucor species, which are more common opportunistic pulmonary pathogens in immunocompromised pediatric patients.

questions.text: Which is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the nervous system? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA)

 

Explanation:


GABA is the major inhibitory mediator in the brain, mediating both presynaptic and postsynaptic inhibition. It's formed by decarboxylation of glutamate by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) in nerve endings throughout the brain. GABA mediates inhibition by increasing Cl⁻ conductance through GABAA receptors, producing hyperpolarization, or by activating GABAB receptors which increase K⁺ conductance and inhibit Ca²⁺ influx.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Glutamate - Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain and spinal cord, responsible for approximately 75% of the excitatory transmission in the CNS. It produces excitation through AMPA, kainate, and NMDA receptors.
  • Option b. Aspartate - While aspartate can function as a neurotransmitter, it is not a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.
  • Option d. Taurine - Taurine is not a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the nervous system.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

GABA is the principal inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS, acting through ionotropic GABAA receptors (which increase Cl⁻ conductance) and metabotropic GABAB receptors (which increase K⁺ conductance and inhibit Ca²⁺ channels).

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture 

 

  • A Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is associated with displacement due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. 

 

 

  • This type of fracture typically occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury). 
  • The mechanism of injury and the specific displacement due to muscle pull are characteristic of Bennett's fracture.
  • The shaft of the metacarpal is laterally dislocated by the unopposedpull of the abductor pollicis longus. 
  • The medial projection of the metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches remains in place. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture is common in young adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it involves the scaphoid bone in the wrist, not the base of the first metacarpal.

 

 

Option C. Rolando fracture: This is also an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal (T or Y) but involves comminution without displacement.

 

 

Option D. Colles fracture: A Colles' fracture is a distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement, commonly seen in older adults after a fall on an outstretched hand, but it does not involve the first metacarpal.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling, compressing the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nests and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the cell of origin of this tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parafollicular C cells

 

The presence of amyloid stroma in the context of a thyroid tumor is indicative of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. These cells are responsible for secreting calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The amyloid stroma seen in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin-derived polypeptides.

 

Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a unique type of thyroid cancer that originates from parafollicular C cells. The hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, which results from calcitonin secretion by these cells.

 

Note -

 

  • The tumor marker for Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC) is thyroglobulin.
  • The tumor marker for Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) is calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Askanazy cells: These cells, also known as Hurthle cells, are large eosinophilic cells found in the thyroid gland but are typically associated with Hurthle cell carcinoma, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Hurthle cells: These cells are a variant of follicular cells and are characteristic of Hurthle cell carcinoma. They do not produce amyloid stroma.

 

Option D. Follicular cells: These cells give rise to other types of thyroid cancers, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) and follicular thyroid carcinoma (FTC). These tumors do not typically feature amyloid stroma and are more commonly associated with thyroglobulin as a tumor marker, not calcitonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by amyloid stroma and originates from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 18-year-old patient with anasarca is found to have proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, increased cholesterol levels, and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following is a recommended treatment for this individual? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prednisolone

 

The clinical presentation describes classic nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and increased cholesterol levels. In such cases, especially in younger patients, the initial treatment is prednisolone, an immunosuppressive therapy aimed at reducing podocyte damage. The goal is to control proteinuria and prevent further kidney damage.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Intravenous albumin: Not an effective long-term treatment. Albumin infusion is ineffective because the patient continues to lose albumin through urine, making it a temporary and ultimately futile intervention.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: This is a more aggressive immunosuppressive therapy typically reserved for steroid-resistant or more severe cases of nephrotic syndrome, not as first-line treatment.

 

Option D. Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is usually considered only in advanced or treatment-resistant cases, not as initial management for a typical nephrotic syndrome presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Prednisolone is the first-line immunosuppressive treatment for nephrotic syndrome, particularly in younger patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of ABPA? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Distal bronchiectasis

 

ABPA is diagnosed based on ISHAM criteria which requires the following:

  1. Predisposing Condition: Asthma/Cystic fibrosis
  2. Mandatory Criteria:
    • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/mL
    • Aspergillus specific IgE >0.35kU/L(OR) +ve skin test against A. fumigatus. (Test indicates sensitization/Type1 HSN reaction)
  3. Supportive Criteria (≥2 should be present):
    • Total eosinophil > 500 cells/mm3
    • Aspergillus specific IgG
    • Radiology Typical for ABPA
      • Central and proximal cylindrical bronchiectasis
      • Alterations predominantly in the upper lobe
      • Nodules
      • Atelectasis
      • Air trapping

 

Note: HAM (High attenuation mucus) is pathognomonic feature of ABPA on HRCT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cough: Cough is a typical symptom of ABPA, resulting from airway inflammation and response to mucus production.

 

Option C. Wheezing: Wheezing in ABPA is due to airway obstruction caused by mucus plugging and inflammation.

 

Option D. Raised serum IgE levels: Elevated IgE levels are a hallmark of ABPA, reflecting the immune system’s hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus.

 

Educational Objective:


Central and proximal bronchiectasis, not distal bronchiectasis, is a characteristic radiological finding in ABPA, helping to differentiate it from other pulmonary conditions. The presence of cough, wheezing, and significantly raised serum IgE levels are supportive of the diagnosis.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia/Chap 288

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis underwent CBNAAT testing and is started on HRZE. CBNAAT is helpful for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation

 

Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin (RIF).

 

It is highly effective for diagnosing tuberculosis and determining rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance. This allows for quick initiation of appropriate therapy, especially important in cases of drug-resistant TB

 

  • MTB Detection: CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Rifampicin Resistance: By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB): While CBNAAT detects MTB, it also provides crucial information about rifampicin resistance, making option B more accurate.

 

Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not detect isoniazid resistance directly.

 

Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin: CBNAAT does not provide information about ethambutol resistance.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

CBNAAT is a rapid and effective test for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used for cancers can cause hand-foot syndrome? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Hand-foot syndrome, also known as palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia, is a side effect of certain chemotherapy drugs. It is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. This condition is most commonly associated with pyrimidine analogs, such as 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and its prodrug capecitabine. Capecitabine is a widely used chemotherapeutic agent for various cancers, including colorectal and breast cancer, and is well known for causing hand-foot syndrome as a dose-limiting toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide:  This is an alkylating agent used in cancer treatment and does not typically cause hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option B. Bleomycin:  An antitumor antibiotic used in cancer therapy, primarily associated with pulmonary toxicity rather than hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: A microtubule inhibitor used in cancer treatment, which can cause peripheral neuropathy and hypersensitivity reactions, but is not commonly associated with hand-foot syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine, a pyrimidine analog, is the cancer drug most commonly associated with causing hand-foot syndrome, characterized by redness, swelling, and pain in the hands and feet.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumor marker of carcinoid tumor? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-HIAA

 

Carcinoid tumors originate from enterochromaffin cells, which are rich in serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). Serotonin is metabolized to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine are indicative of a carcinoid tumor, particularly when the tumor is active and producing excessive serotonin. This makes 5-HIAA a reliable tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring carcinoid tumors and the associated carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:
